how do I identify Certus constellation

Choices:
A: Cetus is the fourth largest constellation, visible in the months around September just to the south of the ecliptic. Despite its size, Cetus has few bright stars, and because it lies far from the plane of the Milky Way, it also has few deep sky objects.

In truth, Cetus is primarily located to the south of the ecliptic. Therefore, the description in Option A is more accurate in terms of its position.
Finally, both options note that Cetus has few bright stars and is situated far from the plane of the Milky Way, resulting in few deep sky objects. Both of these details are correct.
Given the accurate position relative to the ecliptic, Option A is the correct choice. It provides a precise description of Cetus's location and matches known astronomical information.

A: Cetus is the fourth largest constellation, visible in the months around September just to the south of the ecliptic. Despite its size, Cetus has few bright stars, and because it lies far from the plane of the Milky Way, it also has few deep sky objects.
